title: 103_s1340
content:
The Act may be cited as the "National Community Garden Grant Program Act of 1993". Congress finds that there are thousands of vacant lots in communities across the United States, leading to neighborhood deterioration and feelings of hopelessness. The National Community Garden Grant Program aims to prevent urban blight by beautifying neighborhoods, fostering community development, and promoting nutritional awareness and gardening skills. The purpose of this Act is to establish a national partnership between the Secretaries of Agriculture, Housing and Urban Development, and Health and Human Services. The Secretary of Health and Human Services, along with other government officials and organizations, are working together to promote community gardens across the United States. SEC. 3. DEFINITIONS.

Community garden program includes gardening methods for nutrition, education, and beautification. Secretary refers to the Secretary of Agriculture.

SEC. 4. NATIONAL COMMUNITY GARDEN GRANT PROGRAM. The Secretary will award grants to eligible applicants, including local governments and nonprofits, to conduct community garden programs. Up to 100 grants, not exceeding $20,000 each, will be awarded. The Federal share of the program cost will be 25 percent. The Secretary will award grants for community garden programs, with the Federal share set at 25 percent. Grantees must provide the remaining share through cash, in-kind contributions, or other sources. Grants will be distributed to reflect geographical diversity in the United States. The Secretary will allocate 20% of grant funds to communities with populations under 50,000. Selection criteria will prioritize public-private partnerships and surplus property utilization. The Secretary will certify grantee eligibility and allow the use of other funds in conjunction with funds from this Act. SEC. 5. The Secretary will establish a database to compile information on the National Community Garden Grant Program. Grantees must provide details on Federal funds received. SEC. 6. Grantees can use surplus property for community garden programs. SEC. 7. Profits from community garden projects. SEC. 7. Grantees must use profits from community garden program sales to further carry out the program. SEC. 8. Authorization of appropriations: $2,000,000 for fiscal year 1994 and $2,000,000 for each of fiscal years 1996, 1997, and 1998.
